title: Sense, Sensibility and Taxonomy in Elite Eighteenth Century England

parameters.neodash_person_name1: Fitzroy, Augustus Henry, 3rd Duke of Grafton
parameters.neodash_Event.name: Constantine Phipps Expedition to Arctic
parameters.neodash_event.name: Matthew Flinders Expedition to Australia

reports.title: CONTENTS AND OVERVIEW
reports.query:
DATA

This visual archive of tables and charts, draws on a variety of primary and secondary sources which overlap a range of historical disciplines. 
Where written documents typically focus on aspects of a character, profession or place, these graphs and tables are designed to 
It is presented as a series of graphs and tables designed to coexist alongside a set of biographical profiles centred around the 
cultural, social and professional interactions of forty-eight 'people of interest'; twenty-four men and twenty-four women who have
been selected to stand for their profession, ‘place’  or ‘class’ within elite eighteenth-century society and go on to demonstrate the 
inequity of a culture where elite men were favoured through their access to education, enfranchisement and access to professional organisations. 

In order to highlight these gender differences, men and women are represented in blue and pink throughout, with people 
of interest shown in a darker tone of the same colour. 

While historical figures are often seen in isolation and as one dimensional, these visualisations, alongside their corresponding
biographies, attempt to do address a number of points: 
  
- To bring the hitherto underrepresented characters, interests and collections of my forty-eight subjects to the fore.

- To demonstrate that the complex and diverse sexual relationships experienced by high society during this time were as enigmatic
  and entangled as those of the plants Linnaeus was attempting to systemise.

- To demonstrate the intimacy and ‘smallness’ of elite London society during the long eighteenth-century.

Different visualisations and comparisons are available by clicking on a page name above and specific help can be found on each page. 

It should be noted that this archive is running on free software and as such there are a number of limitations for instance the legends do not match.

reports.title: Connections between forty-eight People of Interest
reports.query:
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1a:Person), (p1b:Person),
r1 = shortestPath((p1a)-[*..3]-(p1b)) 
WHERE p1a.Pair <> p1b.Pair 
RETURN r1

reports.title: Instructions
reports.query: https://annegriffiths.com/phd/pdf/Help.pdf

reports.title: Number of Nodes
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Person) 
RETURN  'Person' as Type, COUNT(p) 
as Count
UNION
MATCH (p:Publication) 
RETURN  'Publication' as Type, COUNT(p) 
as Count
UNION
MATCH (s:Residence) 
RETURN 'Residence' as Type, COUNT(s) 
as Count
UNION
MATCH (s:Society) 
RETURN 'Society' as Type, COUNT(s) 
as Count
UNION

MATCH (s:Institution) 
WHERE s.Insttype = "University"
OPTIONAL MATCH (s:Institution) 
WHERE s.Insttype = "School"
RETURN 'School/University' as Type, COUNT(s) 
as Count
UNION
MATCH (s:Institution) 
WHERE s.Insttype = "Museum"
RETURN 'Museum' as Type, COUNT(s) 
as Count
UNION
MATCH (s:CoffeeHouse) 
RETURN 'CoffeeHouse' as Type, COUNT(s) 
as Count
UNION
MATCH (s:Institution) 
WHERE s.Insttype = "Library"
RETURN 'Library' as Type, COUNT(s) 
as Count
UNION
MATCH (s:Hospital) 
RETURN 'Hospital' as Type, COUNT(s) 
as Count

reports.title: Overview
reports.query:
This series of graphs is designed to highlight the familial and social relationships, education and professional achievments 
for each of the forty-eight 'people of interest'. By selecting one name from the table below you can see a series of visualisations
alongside written text which supports and contextualises information shown on the graph.

reports.title: $neodash_poiperson_name
reports.query:
match (p:Person)
where p.Pair
is not null 
return p.name as Name, toString(p.pdf) as Info,
 p.Pairclass as Class
order by p.name

reports.title: $neodash_poiperson_name:
reports.query: https://annegriffiths.com/phd/pdf/$neodash_poiperson_info

reports.title: $neodash_poiperson_name: Education
reports.query:
match (p1:Person) 
where p1.name = $neodash_poiperson_name
with p1
optional match (p1)-[rp1:Studied_at]-(place)
optional match (p1)-[rp4:Apprentice_to]-(person)
optional match (p1)-[rp5:Apprentice_at]-(place)
optional match (tutor)-[rp2:Taught]-(p1)
optional match (tutor)-[rp3:Worked_at]-(place)
return p1, rp1, place, person, tutor, rp2, rp3, rp4, rp5

reports.title: $neodash_poiperson_name: Familial Relationships
reports.query:
MATCH (p1:Person) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_poiperson_name
WITH p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with]-(pp1:Person)
optional match (p2)-[rp2:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with|Guardian]-(pp1:Person)
//optional match r1 = shortestPath((p1)-[*..3]-(p2)) where p1 <> p2
optional match (pp1)-[rp3:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling]-(pp1) where pp1 <> pp1
// Match secondary family relationships with persons of interest (in laws)
OPTIONAL MATCH (pp1)-[rpany:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with]-(p2) where p2:Person and p2.Pair is not NULL
// Match other incidental family relationships with persons of interest (in laws)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p2)-[rpanymore:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with|Engaged_to]-(pp2) where pp2:Person and pp2.Pair is not NULL
RETURN p1, p2, rp1, rp2, pp1, pp2, rp3, rpany, rpanymore //, rp3, p2,  pp2, rany

reports.title: All Relationships for $neodash_poiperson_name
reports.query:
match (p1:Person) 
where p1.name = $neodash_poiperson_name
with p1
optional match (p1)-[rp1]-(anything)
return p1,  rp1, anything

reports.title: $neodash_poiperson_name: Professional Acheivements and Patronages
reports.query:
MATCH (p1:Person) 
WHERE p1.Name = $neodash_poiperson_name
WITH p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r12:Worked_for|Worked_at|Member]-(e1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r13:Commissioned|Published|Wrote|Contributed_to]-(b1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (b2)-[r14:Attributed_to]-(p1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r16:Patron_of]-(p2)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p3)-[r17:Patron_of]-(p1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (b3)-[rpany:Responded]-(b2) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (b4)-[rpany1:Responded]-(b1) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (p4)-[rpwrote:Wrote]-(b3) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (p5)-[rpwrote1:Wrote]-(b4) 


RETURN p1, p2, p3, p4, p5, r12, r13, r14, r16, r17, rpany, rpany1, rpwrote, rpwrote1, b1, b2, b3, b4, e1

reports.title: $neodash_poiperson_name: Friends, Travelling Companions and Correspondents
reports.query:
match (p1:Person) 
where p1.Name = $neodash_poiperson_name
with p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r:Corresponded]-(corres1) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (corres2)-[r1:Corresponded]-(p1) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (c:Person)-[r2:Friend|Travelled_with]-(p1) 
return p1, corres1, corres2, r, r1, r2, c

reports.title: Person1: $neodash_person_name1
reports.query:
match (p:Person)
where p.Pair
is not null 
return p.name as Name1, 
p.Sex as Gender, p.Pairclass as Class
order by p.name

reports.title: Pairs Explorer - Family Relationships
reports.query:
match (p1:Person) 
where p1.name = $neodash_person_name1 or
p1.name = $neodash_person_name2
with p1
optional match (p1)-[rp1:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with]-(pp1:Person)
optional match (p2)-[rp2:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with]-(pp1:Person)
//optional match r1 = shortestPath((p1)-[*..3]-(p2)) where p1 <> p2
optional match (p1)-[rp3:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with]-(p2) where p1 <> p2
return p1,  rp1, pp1, rp3 //, p2, rp2, pp2, rany

reports.title: Person2: $neodash_person_name2
reports.query:
match (p2:Person)
where p2.Pair is not null
return p2.name as Name2,
p2.Sex as Gender2, p2.Pairclass as Class
order by p2.name

reports.title: People in database
reports.query:
match (p:Person)
return count(p)

reports.title: Shortest Path between People of Interest
reports.query:
MATCH p=shortestPath(
(:Person {name:$neodash_person_name1})-[*]-(:Person {name:$neodash_person_name2})
)
RETURN *

reports.title: String to search for
reports.query: RETURN true;

settings.description: Please type a name or subset of the name exactly as it would appear in the archive. For people the

reports.title: Returned names
reports.query:
match (p) where toLower(p.name) CONTAINS toLower(toString($neodash_name))
return labels(p) as Type,
p.name as Name, 
p.Shortname as Display_Name, 
tostring(p.Born.year) as Born, tostring(p.Died.year) as Died, 
tostring(p.From.year) as From, tostring(p.To.year) as To,
tostring(p.Date.year) as Date
order by Type, Name, Display_Name, Date, Born, Died, From, To

reports.title: All Relationships for $neodash_search_Gen_name
reports.query:
match (p1) 
where p1.name = $neodash_search_Gen_name
with p1
optional match (p1)-[rp1]-(anything)
optional match (anything1)-[rp2]-(p1)
return p1,  rp1, rp2, anything, anything1

reports.title: $neodash_search_Gen_name Professional Relationships and Achievements
reports.query:
MATCH (p1) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_search_Gen_name 
WITH p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r12:Worked_for|Worked_at|Member]-(e1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r13:Commissioned|Corresponded|Published|Wrote|Contributed_to|Supplied_specimens]-(b1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (b2)-[r14:Attributed_to]-(p1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r16:Patron_of]-(p2)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p3)-[r17:Patron_of]-(p1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (b3)-[rpany:Responded]-(b2) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (b4)-[rpany1:Responded]-(b1) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (p4)-[rpwrote:Wrote]-(b3) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (p5)-[rpwrote1:Wrote]-(b4) 
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rpded:Dedicated|Illustrated_in]-(b5) 


RETURN p1, p2, p3, p4, p5, r12, r13, r14, r16, r17, rpany, rpany1, rpwrote, rpwrote1, rpded, b1, b2, b3, b4, b5, e1

match  (p1) 
where p1.name = $neodash_search_Gen_name
with p1
optional match (p1)-[rp1:Parent|Spouse|Kin|Sibling|Cohabited_with|Guardian]-(pp1)
//optional match r1 = shortestPath((p1)-[*..3]-(p2)) where p1 <> p2
return p1,  rp1, pp1 //, p2, rp2, pp2, rany

where p1.name = $neodash_search_Gen_name

return p1, p2, r12
//return p1

reports.title: $neodash_search_Gen_name and Spouse: Friends, Correspondents, Clubs and Societies
reports.query:
MATCH (p1) MATCH (p1) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_search_Gen_name 
WITH p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p2)-[r13:Friend|Member|Corresponded_with | Travelled_with]-(p1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r12:Friend|Member|Corresponded_with | Travelled_with]-(p3)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[r14:Spouse]-(s1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (s2)-[r14a:Spouse]-(p1)             // Spouse in either direction
OPTIONAL MATCH (p4)-[r15:Friend|Member|Corresponded_with | Travelled_with]-(s1)
OPTIONAL MATCH (s1)-[r16:Friend|Member|Corresponded_with | Travelled_with]-(p5)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p6)-[r17:Friend|Member|Corresponded_with | Travelled_with]-(s2)    // Friends in either directon
OPTIONAL MATCH (s2)-[r18:Friend|Member|Corresponded_with | Travelled_with]-(p7)

RETURN   p1, p2, p3, s1, s2, p4, p5, p6, p7, r12, r13, r14, r15, r16, r17, r18

settings.description: This report shows important friends, correspondents, traveling companions together with the clubs and societies for both the selected target and their spouse.

reports.title: Overview
reports.query:
REPORT by CLASS and ORDER

Select a Male Class or Female Order from the highlighted lists below to see other individuals whose 'Occupation' matches.

reports.title: List of Male Classes
reports.query:
match (p:Person)
where p.Pairclass 
is not null and p.PairSex = "Male"
//return p.Pair as Pair, p.Name as Name1,
//p.Sex as Gender,  
RETURN p.Pair as No, p.Pairclass as Class, p.name as Name
order by p.Pair

reports.title: Individuals included in Class $neodash_pair_class
reports.query:
match (p:Person)
where p.Occupation CONTAINS $neodash_pair_class
//RETURN p
return p.name as Name,
p.Sex as Sex,  
p.Occupation as Class
order by p.name

reports.title: List of Female Orders
reports.query:
match (p:Person)
where p.Pairclass 
is not null and p.PairSex = "Female"
//return p.Pair as Pair, p.Name as Name1,
//p.Sex as Gender,  
RETURN p.Pair as No, p.Pairclass as Order, p.name as Name 
order by p.Pair

reports.title: Individuals included in Order $neodash_pair_order
reports.query:
match (p:Person)
where p.Occupation CONTAINS $neodash_pair_order
//RETURN p
return p.name as Name,
p.Sex as Sex,  
p.Occupation as Order
order by p.name

reports.title: Apostles of Linnaeus
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Person)-[r:Apostle_of]->(l:Person) 
WHERE l.name = "Linnaeus, Carl"
WITH p, r, l
OPTIONAL MATCH (p)-[r1:Worked_for|Worked_at]->(pl:Company)
RETURN p, l, pl, r, r1

reports.title: Exchange of Specimens between Herbariums
reports.query:
MATCH p=()-[r:Supplied_specimens]->(h:Herbarium) 
RETURN p, h

reports.title: Exchange of Specimens between Botanists
reports.query:
MATCH p=()-[r:Supplied_specimens]->(p1:Person) 
WHERE p1.Occupation CONTAINS "Botanist"
RETURN p, p1

reports.title: Supply and Exchange of Specimens between Botanic Gardens
reports.query:
MATCH p=()-[r:Supplied_specimens]->(g:Garden) 
RETURN p, g

reports.title: Plants Named After
reports.query:
MATCH p=(:Plant)-[r:Named_after]->(pe:Person) 
OPTIONAL MATCH pe1=(:Person)-[r1:Named]->(p1:Plant) 
RETURN p, pe, p1, pe1, r, r1

reports.title: Map of Botanic Gardens
reports.query:
match (g:Garden)
where g.location is not null
return g

reports.title: Botanic Gardens
reports.query:
match (g:Garden)
where g.location is not null
return 
Labels(g),
g.name as Name,
g.Type as Type, 
g.Country as Country
order by g.name

reports.title: Societies in Database
reports.query:
match (p:Society) 
return count(p)

reports.title: Societies of Interest: $neodash_society_name
reports.query:
match (p:Society)
where p.Interest = "Y"
return p.name as Name
order by p.name

reports.title: $neodash_society_name: Membership
reports.query:
match (s1:Society) 
where s1.name = $neodash_society_name
with s1
optional match (p1:Person)-[rp1:Member|Founded|Associated]-(s1)
optional match (s1)-[rp2:Met_at]-(pl)
return p1, rp1, s1, rp2, pl

reports.title: Instructions
reports.query:
Select one Society from the table below
to show the membership and meeting places of 
societies of special interest.
To enquire on other Societies, please use 
the General Search page.

reports.title: Society: $neodash_society_name
reports.query:
match (s1:Society)
where s1.name = $neodash_society_name
return  s1.Membership as 
Membership, s1.Soctype as Type, s1.Proftype as Profession_Interest, s1.Ref as Reference

reports.title: Societies of Interest
Smallpox Vaccination
reports.query:
// Return Variolation
MATCH  (pa:Publication), (h:Hospital), (r:Procedure)
WHERE  pa.Subject CONTAINS "Vaccination" OR pa.Subject CONTAINS "Variolation" OR
r.name CONTAINS "Variolation" and h.Type CONTAINS "Variolation"
with pa, r, h
optional MATCH (p:Person)-[q:Rejected | Studied | Endorsed]->(r)    
optional MATCH (p1:Person)-[q1:Wrote | Commissioned | Contributed_to]->(pa)   
optional MATCH (pa1:Publication)-[q2:Responded]->(pa)  
optional MATCH (pa)-[q3:Translated_as]->(pa2) 
optional MATCH (p3)-[q4:Worked_at | Founded]->(h) 
RETURN p, p1, pa2, p3, h, pa, r, q, q1, q2, q3, q4

reports.title: Midwifery
TEST MATERNITY
reports.query:
MATCH (o:Person|Publication|Hospital)-[r1:Rejected|Endorsed|Wrote|Commissioned|Contributed_to|Responded|Translated_as|Worked_at|Founded|Taught|Studied_at]-(o2:Person|Publication|Hospital)
WHERE
(o.Occupation CONTAINS "idwife" or
o.Type CONTAINS "Maternity" or
o.Subject CONTAINS "Midwifery") AND
(o2.Occupation CONTAINS "idwife" or
o2.Type CONTAINS "Maternity" or
o2.Subject CONTAINS "Midwifery")
return o, r1, o2

reports.title: Physicians

reports.query:
// Return Taught Maternity
MATCH  (h:Hospital), (i:Institution)
WHERE   h.Type CONTAINS "Maternity" or i.name contains "Maternity"
   with h
    match p=()-[r:Worked_at | Taught | Founded]->(h) 
 optional match p=()-[r:Worked_at | Taught | Founded]->(s) 
optional match p=()- [Taught]-> (p1)
optional match p2=()- [Taught]-> (p)
   
return p, h, s, p1, p2

reports.title: Expeditions
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Event) 
WHERE p.Eventype contains "Expedition"
return p.name as Name
order by p.Name

reports.title: Expeditions in Database
$neodash_event_name
reports.query:
MATCH (p1) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_event_name
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1]-(anything)
RETURN p1, rp1, anything

reports.title: Catalogue of Objects
reports.query:
match (p:Object)
return p.name as Object, p.Type as Type, p.Material as Material
order by p.Type

reports.title: $neodash_object
reports.query:
MATCH (p1:Object) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_object
//WITH p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1:Compiled |Commissioned | Designed | Produced | Wrote | Illustrated]-(pp1:Person)                           // person's children
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp2:Owned| Given]-(pp2:Person)                           // person's children
RETURN p1, pp1,pp2, rp1, rp2

reports.title: Subject Categories
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Publication)  
//Where count(p.Subject) as count
RETURN distinct(p.Subject) as Subject
ORDER by p.Subject

reports.title: Publictions by Subject and Title
reports.query:
Publications include Books, Poems, Plays and Music.

Publications are inherently difficult to categorise as they cover multiple subjects, so it may be necessary to scrutinise more than one topic, however a first pass follows:-  
  Gardening tries to address books for the non professional, Agriculture, for the commercial producer, and Horticulture/Floriculture
for the kitchen garden. Similarly Botany for its own sake overlaps with the Herbal and the subject of Medicine. Eductation and Morals have been grouped together. 

Select a category from the drop down list and you will see a visualisation chart showing the publications within this category together with their author. This chart
demonstrates how particular topics were typically addressed by one sex or the other. Below is a table of these books by title and language; from this list you can
select a particular title for more information and links to those available online.

reports.title: Publications on Subject $neodash_Book_Subject
reports.query:
match (p1:Publication) 
where  p1.Subject CONTAINS $neodash_Book_Subject
return p1.name as Name, p1.Pubtype as Type, p1.Author as Author, 
p1.Language as Language, toString(p1.Date.year) as Published
Order by Name, Author

reports.title: $neodash_Book_Name
reports.query:
match (p1:Publication) 
where p1.name CONTAINS $neodash_Book_Name
with p1
optional match (p1)-[rp1]-(anything)
optional match (anything1)-[rp2]-(p1)
return p1,  rp1, rp2, anything, anything1

reports.title: Authors on Subject  $neodash_Book_Subject
reports.query:
match (p1:Publication) 
where p1.Subject CONTAINS $neodash_Book_Subject
with p1
optional match (p1)-[rp1:Wrote |Published]-(p2)

return p1,  rp1, p2

reports.title: Parental Relationships for $neodash_famperson_name
reports.query:
MATCH (p1:Person) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_famperson_name
//WITH p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1:Parent]-(pp1:Person)                           // person's children
OPTIONAL MATCH (p2)-[rp2:Parent]-(pp1:Person)                           // childrens' other parent
OPTIONAL MATCH (p2)-[rparent]-(p1)                                      // relationship beteen parents

OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp3:Kin{Relationship:"Step-parent"}]-(pp2:Person)  // person's stepchildren

OPTIONAL MATCH (pp1)-[rp4:Parent]-(p4)                                  // childrens' children (person's grandchildren) where pp1 <> pp1
OPTIONAL MATCH (pp1)-[rp5:Kin{Relationship:"Step-parent"}]-(p5:Person)  // childrens' stepchildren where pp1 <> pp1

//OPTIONAL MATCH (pp1)-[rpany:Parent]-(p2) where p2:Person  ?
// Match other incidental family relationships with persons of interest (in laws)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p2)-[rpanymore:Parent]-(pp2:Person)                     // other parent's other children
OPTIONAL MATCH (p5)-[rpanymor1:Parent]-(pp3:Person)                     // grandchildrens' other parent (note for Beauclark)
RETURN pp1, pp2, pp3, p1, p2, p4, p5, rp5, rp4, rp3, rp2, rp1, rpanymore, rpanymor1, rparent
//,   pp2, rp3, rpany, rpanymore // //, rp3, p2,  pp2, rany

reports.title: Family Name or Maiden Name contains '$neodash_famname'
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Person)
WHERE toLower(p.name) CONTAINS toLower(toString($neodash_famname))
OR 
toLower(p.Née) CONTAINS toLower(toString($neodash_famname))
OR 
toLower(p.Né) CONTAINS toLower(toString($neodash_famname))
OR 
toLower(p.Aka) CONTAINS toLower(toString($neodash_famname))
RETURN p.name as Name, p.Née as Née, p.Né as Né, p.Aka as Other_names, p.Sex as Sex
ORDER BY Name, Née, Né, Other_names, Sex

reports.title: Family Name
reports.query: RETURN true;

reports.title: Sibling Relationships for $neodash_famperson_name
reports.query:
MATCH (p1:Person) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_famperson_name
WITH p1
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1:Sibling]-(pp1:Person)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p2)-[rp2:Kin{Relationship:"Half"}]-(pp2:Person)
RETURN p1, p2, rp1, rp2, pp1, pp2

reports.title: 'Other' Relationships for $neodash_famperson_name
reports.query:
MATCH (p1:Person) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_famperson_name
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1:Spouse]-(pp1:Person)
OPTIONAL MATCH (pp1)-[rp2:Spouse]-(p1:Person)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp3:Lover]-(pp2:Person)
OPTIONAL MATCH (pp3)-[rp4:Lover]-(p1:Person)
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp5:Kin]-(pp4:Person)
OPTIONAL MATCH (pp5)-[rp6:Kin]-(p1:Person)
RETURN p1, rp1, rp2, rp3, rp4, rp5, rp6,  pp1, pp2, pp3, pp4, pp5

reports.title: Divorces
reports.query:
MATCH (wife)-[r]-(husband) where (r.Divorced) IS NOT NULL
OPTIONAL MATCH (lover:Person) where lover.name = r.Lover
OPTIONAL MATCH (wife:Person)-[rl:Lover]-(lover:Person) 
RETURN DISTINCT wife, husband, lover, r, rl

reports.title: Criminal Conversations
reports.query:
MATCH p=(wife:Person)-[r:Spouse]-(husband:Person) WHERE (r.Crimcon) IS NOT NULL 
OPTIONAL MATCH (lover:Person) where lover.name = r.Lover
OPTIONAL MATCH (wife:Person)-[rl:Lover]-(lover:Person) 
RETURN DISTINCT wife, husband, lover, r, rl

reports.title: Politicians of Great Britain
reports.query:
// Return Node
MATCH (f1)
WHERE f1.Occupation contains "Politician" 
RETURN f1.name as Name, f1.Politics as Party
order by Name

reports.title: Prime Ministers of Great Britain
Eighteenth-century Politics
reports.query:
The 18th century was a period dominated by two political parties. The early years were controlled by the Whigs, usually members of the aristocratic elite who opposed absolute monarchy and Catholic emancipation and exercised influence through their connections and patronages. Their great leader, regarded as Britain’s first prime minister, was Robert Walpole (1676-1745), who controlled the government from 1721 to 1742. In the latter half of the century following George III ‘s (1738-1820) accession in1760,  the leading conservative group, the Tories, saw a resurgence in power and John Stuart, 3rd Earl of Bute, a close friend and former tutor of the King, become the first Tory prime minister in 1762. 

The House of Commons consisted entirely of men; women could neither vote nor stand for election. As Members of Parliament were not paid, only men with an independent income could stand for election which meant that candidates typically came from the landed gentry, i.e. they owned land, property or business, and were the relatives of the peers who sat in of the House of Lords. 

With only about 200,000 property-owning men having the right to vote, many constituencies were considered  ‘pocket boroughs’, owned outright by a major landowner whose tenants were obliged to vote as he directed or face eviction. While in some boroughs known as ‘rotten boroughs’, there were very few voters, in Old Sarum none at all, and those there were could be easily bribed to return representatives in the rapidly expanding new towns, such as Manchester, there was no direct parliamentary representation at all.

reports.title: Properties in Database
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Residence) 
return count(p)

reports.title: Properties sorted by name
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Residence) 
return p.name as Name, p.Location as Location, p.Country as Country
order by p.Name

reports.title: $neodash_residence_name
reports.query:
MATCH (p1) 
WHERE p1.name = $neodash_residence_name
OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1]-(anything)
RETURN p1, rp1, anything

reports.title: Property sorted by Location
reports.query:
MATCH (p:Residence) 
return p.name as Name, p.Location as Location, p.Country as Country
order by p.Location, p.Country, p.Name

reports.title: Property in $neodash_location_name
reports.query:
MATCH (p1) 
WHERE p1.Location = $neodash_location_name
//OPTIONAL MATCH (p1)-[rp1]-(anything)
RETURN p1
